{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Gastritis | image = Gastritis helicobacter - intermed mag.jpg | caption = [[Micrograph]] showing gastritis. [[H&E stain]]. | field = [[Gastroenterology]] | symptoms = Upper [[abdominal pain]], [[nausea]], [[vomiting]], bloating, loss of appetite, [[heartburn]]<ref name=NID2013/><ref name=Rosen2012/> | complications = [[Bleeding]], [[Peptic ulcer|stomach ulcer]]s, [[stomach tumor]]s, [[pernicious anemia]]<ref name=NID2013/><ref name=Var2014/> | onset = | duration = Short or long term<ref name=NID2013/> | types = | causes = ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]'', [[NSAIDs]], [[Ethanol|alcohol]], [[smoking]], [[cocaine]], severe illness, [[autoimmune]] problems<ref name=NID2013/> | risks = | diagnosis = [[Endoscopy]], [[upper gastrointestinal series]], blood tests, stool tests<ref name=NID2013/> | differential = [[Myocardial infarction]], [[pancreatitis|inflammation of the pancreas]], [[biliary colic|gallbladder problems]], [[peptic ulcer disease]]<ref name=Rosen2012/> | prevention = | treatment = [[Antacid]]s, [[H2 blockers]], [[proton pump inhibitors]], [[antibiotic]]s<ref name=NID2013/> | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = ~50% of people<ref name=Ferri2013/> | deaths = 50,000 (2015)<ref name=GBD2015De/> }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''Gastritis''' is [[inflammation]] of the lining of the [[stomach]].<ref name=NID2013/> It may occur as a [[acute (medicine)|short episode]] or may be of a [[chronic (medicine)|long duration]].<ref name=NID2013/> There may be no symptoms but, when symptoms are present, the most common is upper [[abdominal pain]].<ref name=NID2013/> Other possible symptoms include [[nausea]] and [[vomiting]], bloating, loss of appetite and [[heartburn]].<ref name=NID2013/><ref name=Rosen2012>{{cite book|title=Rosen & Barkin's 5-Minute Emergency Medicine Consult|date=2012|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=9781451160970|page=447|edition=4|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=3JNUG-m0650C&pg=PA447|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402085944/https://books.google.ca/books?id=3JNUG-m0650C&pg=PA447|archivedate=2015-04-02|df=}}</ref> Complications may include [[bleeding]], [[Peptic ulcer|stomach ulcer]]s, and [[stomach tumor]]s.<ref name=NID2013/> When due to [[autoimmune gastritis|autoimmune problems]], [[anemia|low red blood cell]]s due to not enough [[vitamin B12]] may occur, a condition known as [[pernicious anemia]].<ref name=Var2014>{{Cite journal | last1 = Varbanova | first1 = M. | last2 = Frauenschläger | first2 = K. | last3 = Malfertheiner | first3 = P. | title = Chronic gastritis - an update. | journal = Best Pract Res Clin Gastroenterol | volume = 28 | issue = 6 | pages = 1031–42 |date=Dec 2014 | doi = 10.1016/j.bpg.2014.10.005 | PMID = 25439069 }}</ref>
<!-- Cause and diagnosis --> Common causes include infection with ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]'' and use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs ([[NSAIDs]]).<ref name=NID2013/> Less common causes include [[Ethanol|alcohol]], [[smoking]], [[cocaine]], severe illness, autoimmune problems, [[radiation therapy]] and [[Crohn's disease]].<ref name=NID2013>{{cite web|title=Gastritis|url=http://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-topics/digestive-diseases/gastritis/Pages/facts.aspx|website=The National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)|accessdate=1 March 2015|date=November 27, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150306172839/http://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-topics/digestive-diseases/gastritis/Pages/facts.aspx|archivedate=6 March 2015|df=}}</ref><ref name=Mayo2014>{{cite book|author1=Hauser, Stephen|title=Mayo Clinic Gastroenterology and Hepatology Board Review|date=2014|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199373338|pages=49|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=1bITBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA49|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305051031/https://books.google.ca/books?id=1bITBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA49|archivedate=2016-03-05|df=}}</ref> [[Endoscopy]], a type of [[radiography|X-ray]] known as an [[upper gastrointestinal series]], blood tests, and stool tests may help with diagnosis.<ref name=NID2013/> The symptoms of gastritis may be a presentation of a [[myocardial infarction]].<ref name=Rosen2012/> Other conditions with similar symptoms include [[pancreatitis|inflammation of the pancreas]], [[biliary colic|gallbladder problems]], and [[peptic ulcer disease]].<ref name=Rosen2012/>
<!-- Prevention and treatment --> Prevention is by avoiding things that cause the disease.<ref name=Ferri2013/> Treatment includes medications such as [[antacid]]s, [[H2 blockers]], or [[proton pump inhibitors]].<ref name=NID2013/> During an acute attack drinking [[viscous lidocaine]] may help.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Adams,|title=Emergency Medicine: Clinical Essentials|date=2012|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9781455733941|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=rpoH-KYE93IC&pg=PP1314|chapter=32|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815194518/https://books.google.ca/books?id=rpoH-KYE93IC&pg=PP1314|archivedate=2016-08-15|df=}}</ref> If gastritis is due to NSAIDs these may be stopped.<ref name=NID2013/> If ''H. pylori'' is present it may be treated with a combination of [[antibiotic]]s such as [[amoxicillin]] and [[clarithromycin]].<ref name=NID2013/> For those with pernicious anemia, vitamin B12 supplements are recommended either by mouth or by injection.<ref name=Var2014/> People are usually advised to avoid foods that bother them.<ref name=Hold2012>{{cite book|editor1=Webster-Gandy, Joan|editor2=Madden, Angela |editor3=Holdsworth, Michelle|title=Oxford handbook of nutrition and dietetics|date=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|location=Oxford|isbn=9780199585823|page=571|edition=2nd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8DugwipyfHgC&pg=PA571|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908172055/https://books.google.com/books?id=8DugwipyfHgC&pg=PA571|archivedate=2017-09-08|df=}}</ref>
<!-- Epidemiology and history --> Gastritis is believed to affect about half of people worldwide.<ref name=Ferri2013/> In 2013 there were approximately 90 million new cases of the condition.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Global Burden of Disease Study 2013|first1=Collaborators|title=Global, regional, and national incidence, prevalence, and years lived with disability for 301 acute and chronic diseases and injuries in 188 countries, 1990-2013: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2013.|journal=Lancet|date=22 August 2015|volume=386|issue=9995|pages=743–800|pmid=26063472|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(15)60692-4|pmc=4561509}}</ref> As people get older the disease becomes more common.<ref name=Ferri2013>{{cite book|author1=Fred F. Ferri|title=Ferri's Clinical Advisor 2013,5 Books in 1, Expert Consult - Online and Print,1: Ferri's Clinical Advisor 2013|date=2012|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9780323083737|page=417|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=OR3VERnvzzEC&pg=PA417|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305074639/https://books.google.ca/books?id=OR3VERnvzzEC&pg=PA417|archivedate=2016-03-05|df=}}</ref> It, along with a similar condition in the first part of the [[intestine]]s known as [[duodenitis]], resulted in 50,000 deaths in 2015.<ref name=GBD2015De>{{cite journal|last1=GBD 2015 Mortality and Causes of Death|first1=Collaborators.|title=Global, regional, and national life expectancy, all-cause mortality, and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes of death, 1980-2015: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015.|journal=Lancet|date=8 October 2016|volume=388|issue=10053|pages=1459–1544|pmid=27733281|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(16)31012-1|pmc=5388903}}</ref> ''H. pylori'' was first discovered in 1981 by [[Barry Marshall]] and [[Robin Warren]].<ref name=Wang2011>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=AY|last2=Peura|first2=DA|title=The prevalence and incidence of Helicobacter pylori-associated peptic ulcer disease and upper gastrointestinal bleeding throughout the world.|journal=Gastrointestinal Endoscopy Clinics of North America|date=October 2011|volume=21|issue=4|pages=613–35|pmid=21944414|doi=10.1016/j.giec.2011.07.011}}</ref> {{TOC limit|3}}
== Signs and symptoms == [[Image:Deep gastric ulcer.png|thumb|A peptic ulcer may accompany gastritis. [[Esophagogastroduodenoscopy|Endoscopic image]].]] Many people with gastritis experience no symptoms at all. However, [[epigastrium|upper central]] [[abdominal pain]] is the most common symptom; the pain may be dull, vague, burning, aching, gnawing, sore, or sharp.<ref name="eMed">{{cite news | title=Gastritis Symptoms | year=2008 | publisher=eMedicineHealth | url=http://www.emedicinehealth.com/gastritis/article_em.htm | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-11-18 | language= | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206065449/http://www.emedicinehealth.com/gastritis/article_em.htm | archivedate=2008-12-06 | df= }}</ref> Pain is usually located in the upper central portion of the [[human abdomen|abdomen]],<ref name='NIH Publication No. 05–4764'>{{cite news | title=Gastritis | date=December 2004 | publisher=National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases | url=http://digestive.niddk.nih.gov/ddiseases/pubs/gastritis/ | work=National Digestive Diseases Information Clearinghouse | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-06 | language= | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011181514/http://digestive.niddk.nih.gov/ddiseases/pubs/gastritis | archivedate=2008-10-11 | df= }}</ref> but it may occur anywhere from the upper left portion of the abdomen around to the back.
Other signs and symptoms may include the following: *[[Nausea]] *[[Vomiting]] (may be clear, green or yellow, blood-streaked or completely bloody depending on the severity of the stomach [[inflammation]]) *[[Belching]] (does not usually relieve stomach pain if present) *[[Bloating]] *[[Hunger (motivational state)|Early satiety]]<ref name="eMed" /> *[[Anorexia (symptom)|Loss of appetite]] *[[Weight Loss|Unexplained weight loss]]
== Cause == Common causes include ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]'' and [[NSAIDs]].<!-- <ref name=NID2013/> --> Less common causes include [[Ethanol|alcohol]], [[cocaine]], severe illness and [[Crohn disease]], among others.<ref name=NID2013/>
===''Helicobacter pylori''=== ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]'' colonizes the stomachs of more than half of the world's population, and the infection continues to play a key role in the pathogenesis of a number of gastroduodenal diseases. Colonization of the gastric mucosa with ''Helicobacter pylori'' results in the development of chronic gastritis in infected individuals, and in a subset of patients chronic gastritis progresses to complications (e.g., ulcer disease, [[stomach cancer]]s, some distinct extragastric disorders).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kandulski A, Selgrad M, Malfertheiner P |title=Helicobacter pylori infection: a clinical overview |journal=Digestive and Liver Disease |volume=40 |issue=8 |pages=619–26 |date=August 2008 |pmid=18396114 |doi=10.1016/j.dld.2008.02.026}}</ref> However, over 80 percent of individuals infected with the bacterium are [[asymptomatic]] and it has been postulated that it may play an important role in the natural stomach ecology.<ref>{{Cite journal| last1 = Blaser| first1 = M. J.| authorlink = Martin J. Blaser| title = Who are we? Indigenous microbes and the ecology of human diseases| doi = 10.1038/sj.embor.7400812| journal = EMBO Reports| volume = 7| issue = 10| pages = 956–60| year = 2006| pmid = 17016449| pmc = 1618379| url = http://www.nature.com/embor/journal/v7/n10/pdf/7400812.pdf| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121105233214/http://www.nature.com/embor/journal/v7/n10/pdf/7400812.pdf| archivedate = 2012-11-05| df = }}</ref>
===Critical illness=== Gastritis may also develop after major surgery or traumatic injury ("[[Cushing ulcer]]"), burns ("[[Curling's ulcer|Curling ulcer]]"), or severe infections. Gastritis may also occur in those who have had weight loss surgery resulting in the [[Adjustable gastric band|banding]] or reconstruction of the digestive tract.
===Diet=== Evidence does not support a role for specific foods including spicy foods and coffee in the development of [[peptic ulcers]].<ref>{{cite book|editor1=Raphael Rubin|editor2=David S. Strayer|editor3=Emanuel Rubin|title=Rubin's pathology : clinicopathologic foundations of medicine|date=2012|publisher=Wolters Kluwer Health/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia|isbn=9781605479682|page=623|edition=Sixth|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=wb2TzY9AgJ0C&pg=PA623|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402150147/https://books.google.ca/books?id=wb2TzY9AgJ0C&pg=PA623|archivedate=2015-04-02|df=}}</ref> People are usually advised to avoid foods that bother them.<ref name=Hold2012/>
== Pathophysiology ==
===Acute=== Acute erosive gastritis typically involves discrete foci of surface necrosis due to damage to mucosal defenses.<ref name=merckgastritis>{{cite news | title=Gastritis | date=January 2007 | publisher=Merck | url=http://www.merck.com/mmpe/sec02/ch013/ch013c.html | work= | pages= | accessdate=2009-01-11 | language= | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125094521/http://merck.com/mmpe/sec02/ch013/ch013c.html | archivedate=2009-01-25 | df= }}</ref> NSAIDs inhibit [[cyclooxygenase-1]], or COX-1, an enzyme responsible for the biosynthesis of [[eicosanoids]] in the stomach, which increases the possibility of [[peptic ulcer]]s forming.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dajani EZ, Islam K |title=Cardiovascular and gastrointestinal toxicity of selective cyclo-oxygenase-2 inhibitors in man |journal=J Physiol Pharmacol |volume=59 Suppl 2 |pages=117–33 |date=August 2008 |pmid=18812633 |url=http://www.jpp.krakow.pl/journal/archive/0808_s2/pdf/117_0808_s2_article.pdf |format=PDF }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=Level C |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Also, NSAIDs, such as aspirin, reduce a substance that protects the stomach called [[prostaglandin]]. These drugs used in a short period are not typically dangerous. However, regular use can lead to gastritis.<ref name=Siegelbaum>{{cite news | first=Jackson | last=Siegelbaum | title=Gastritis | year=2006 | publisher=Jackson Siegelbaum Gastroenterology | url=http://www.gicare.com/pated/ecdgs46.htm | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-11-18 | language= | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216012309/http://www.gicare.com/pated/ecdgs46.htm | archivedate=2008-12-16 | df= }}</ref> Additionally, severe physiologic stress ("stress ulcers") from sepsis, hypoxia, trauma, or surgery, is also a common etiology for acute erosive gastritis. This form of gastritis can occur in more than 5% of hospitalized patients.
Also, note that alcohol consumption does not cause chronic gastritis. It does, however, erode the mucosal lining of the stomach; low doses of alcohol stimulate [[hydrochloric acid]] secretion. High doses of alcohol do not stimulate secretion of acid.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wolff G |title=[Effect of alcohol on the stomach] |language=German |journal=Gastroenterol J |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=45–9 |year=1989 |pmid=2679657 |trans-title=Effect of alcohol on the stomach }}</ref>
===Chronic=== [[Chronic gastritis]] refers to a wide range of problems of the gastric tissues.<ref name=merckgastritis/> The immune system makes proteins and antibodies that fight infections in the body to maintain a [[homeostatic]] condition. In some disorders the body targets the stomach as if it were a foreign protein or pathogen; it makes antibodies against, severely damages, and may even destroy the stomach or its lining.<ref name=Siegelbaum/> In some cases bile, normally used to aid digestion in the small intestine, will enter through the [[pyloric valve]] of the stomach if it has been removed during surgery or does not work properly, also leading to gastritis. Gastritis may also be caused by other medical conditions, including [[HIV/AIDS]], [[Crohn's disease]], certain [[connective tissue disease|connective tissue disorders]], and [[liver failure|liver]] or [[renal failure|kidney failure]]. Since 1992, chronic gastritis lesions are classified according to the Sydney system.<ref name='DS00488'>{{cite news | author=Mayo Clinic Staff | title=Gastritis | date=April 13, 2007 | publisher=MayoClinic | url=http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/gastritis/DS00488/DSECTION=causes | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-11-18 | language= | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208050321/http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/gastritis/DS00488/DSECTION%3Dcauses | archivedate=December 8, 2008 | df= }}</ref>
====Metaplasia==== Mucous gland [[metaplasia]], the reversible replacement of differentiated cells, occurs in the setting of severe damage of the gastric glands, which then waste away ([[atrophic gastritis]]) and are progressively replaced by mucous glands. Gastric ulcers may develop; it is unclear if they are the causes or the consequences. Intestinal metaplasia typically begins in response to chronic mucosal injury in the [[antrum]], and may extend to the body. Gastric mucosa cells change to resemble intestinal mucosa and may even assume absorptive characteristics. [[Intestinal metaplasia]] is classified histologically as complete or incomplete. With complete metaplasia, gastric mucosa is completely transformed into small-bowel mucosa, both histologically and functionally, with the ability to absorb nutrients and secrete peptides. In incomplete metaplasia, the epithelium assumes a histologic appearance closer to that of the large intestine and frequently exhibits [[dysplasia]].<ref name=merckgastritis/>
== Diagnosis == Often, a diagnosis can be made based on the patient's description of their symptoms, but other methods which may be used to verify gastritis include: *Blood tests: **[[Complete blood count|Blood cell count]] **Presence of ''H. pylori'' **[[Liver]], [[kidney]], [[gallbladder]], or [[pancreas]] functions *[[Urinalysis]] *Stool sample, to look for blood in the stool *X-rays *Endoscopy, to check for stomach lining inflammation and mucous erosion *Stomach biopsy, to test for gastritis and other conditions<ref>{{cite news | title=Exams and Tests | year=2008 | publisher=eMedicinHealth | url=http://www.emedicinehealth.com/gastritis/page3_em.htm | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-11-18 | language= | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211013501/http://www.emedicinehealth.com/gastritis/page3_em.htm | archivedate=2008-12-11 | df= }}</ref>
==Treatment== [[Antacid]]s are a common treatment for mild to medium gastritis.<ref name="Overview">{{cite journal|last1=Zajac|first1=P|last2=Holbrook|first2=A|last3=Super|first3=ME|last4=Vogt|first4=M |title=An overview: Current clinical guidelines for the evaluation, diagnosis, treatment, and management of dyspepsia|journal=Osteopathic Family Physician |volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=79–85 |date=March–April 2013 |pmid=|doi=10.1016/j.osfp.2012.10.005}}</ref> When antacids do not provide enough relief, medications such as [[H2 antagonist|H<sub>2</sub> blockers]] and [[proton-pump inhibitors]] that help reduce the amount of acid are often prescribed.<ref name="Overview"/><ref name="pmid18457460">{{cite journal |vauthors=Boparai V, Rajagopalan J, Triadafilopoulos G |title=Guide to the use of proton pump inhibitors in adult patients |journal=Drugs |volume=68 |issue=7 |pages=925–47 |year=2008 |pmid=18457460 |doi=10.2165/00003495-200868070-00004}}</ref>
Cytoprotective agents are designed to help protect the tissues that line the stomach and small intestine.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fashner|first1=J|last2=Gitu|first2=AC|title=Diagnosis and Treatment of Peptic Ulcer Disease and H. pylori Infection.|journal=American Family Physician|date=15 February 2015|volume=91|issue=4|pages=236–42|pmid=25955624}}</ref> They include the medications [[sucralfate]] and [[misoprostol]]. If [[NSAID]]s are being taken regularly, one of these medications to protect the stomach may also be taken. Another cytoprotective agent is [[bismuth subsalicylate]] {{citation needed|date=May 2018}}.
Several regimens are used to treat ''H. pylori'' infection. Most use a combination of two [[antibiotics]] and a proton pump inhibitor. Sometimes bismuth is added to the regimen.
==History== In 1,000 A.D, [[Avicenna]] first gave the description of stomach cancer. In 1728, German physician [[Georg Ernst Stahl]] first coined the term "gastritis". Italian anatomical pathologist [[Giovanni Battista Morgagni]] further described the characteristics of gastric inflammation. He described the characteristics of erosive or ulcerative gastritis and erosive gastritis. Between 1808 and 1831, French physician [[François-Joseph-Victor Broussais]] gathered information from the autopsy of the dead French soldiers. He described chronic gastritis as "Gastritide" and erroneously believed that gastritis was the cause of [[ascites]], [[typhoid fever]], and [[meningitis]]. In 1854, [[Charles Handfield Jones]] and [[Wilson Fox]] described the microscopic changes of stomach inner lining in gastritis which existed in diffuse and segmental forms. In 1855, [[Carl von Rokitansky|Baron Carl von Rokitansky]] first described [[hypertrophy|hypetrophic]] gastritis. In 1859, British physician, [[William Brinton]] first described about [[acute (medicine)|acute]], [[subacute]], and [[chronic condition|chronic]] gastritis. In 1870, Samuel Fenwick noted that [[pernicious anemia]] causes glandular [[atrophy]] in gastritis. German surgeon, Georg Ernst Konjetzny noticed that gastric ulcer and gastric cancer are the result of gastric inflammation. [[Shields Warren]] and Willam A. Meissner described the [[intestinal metaplasia]] of the stomach as a feature of chronic gastritis.<ref name="Guyula 2013">{{cite book |last1=Gyula |first1=Mozsik |title=Current Topics in gastritis |date=16 January 2013 |publisher=University of Pécs |isbn=978-953-51-0907-5 |pages=1–19 |url=https://cdn.intechopen.com/pdfs/41544.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2018 |chapter=Chapter 1: Diagnosis of Gastritis – Review from Early Pathological Evaluation to Present Day Management}}</ref>

'''Gastrophysics''' (gastronomical physics) is an emerging interdisciplinary science that employs principles from [[physics]] and [[chemistry]] to attain a fundamental understanding of the worlds of [[gastronomy]] and [[cooking]]. Gastrophysical topics of interest includes investigations of the raw materials of food, the effects of food preparation, and quantitative aspects of the physical basis for food quality, [[flavour]], appreciation and absorption in the human body.<ref name=Mouritsen2012>{{cite journal|last1=Mouritsen|first1=Ole G|title=The emerging science of gastrophysics and its application to the algal cuisine|journal=Flavour|date=2012|volume=1|issue=1|pages=6|doi=10.1186/2044-7248-1-6}}</ref><ref name =MouritsenRisbo2013>{{cite journal|last1=Mouritsen|first1=Ole G|last2=Risbo|first2=Jens|title=Gastrophysics-do we need it?|journal=Flavour|date=2013|volume=2|issue=1|pages=3|doi=10.1186/2044-7248-2-3}}</ref>
== Definition and aim == Gastrophysics is a scientific discipline that focuses on investigations of aspects of [[gastronomy]] and [[cooking]] that relates to phenomena, which can be described and explained in a frame of [[physics]], [[physical chemistry]], [[chemistry]], and associated sciences.<ref name=Mouritsen2016>{{cite journal|last1=G. Mouritsen|first1=Ole|title=Gastrophysics of the Oral Cavity|journal=Current Pharmaceutical Design|date=27 April 2016|volume=22|issue=15|pages=2195–2203|doi=10.2174/1381612822666160219120940}}</ref>
The source of inspiration for gastrophysics is [[gastronomy]] and [[cooking]]. Gastrophysical studies has a gastronomic observation as its starting point, and aims at unravelling the scientific nature of the observations on many different length scales, including explaining physical and chemical aspects of the raw materials, of their transformations during the preparation of food, as well as of the [[Sensory perception|sensory]] response while eating <ref name=MouritsenRisbo2013 /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vilgis|first1=Thomas A|title=Texture, taste and aroma: multi-scale materials and the gastrophysics of food|journal=Flavour|date=2013|volume=2|issue=1|pages=12|doi=10.1186/2044-7248-2-12}}</ref>
The chemical and physical composition and properties of raw food materials are important for the transformations that occur in the food during preparation (heating, cooling, mixing, beating, [[fermenting]], [[Salting (food)|salting]], [[drying]], [[Smoking (cooking)|smoking]], [[souring]] etc.).<ref>{{cite book|last1=McGee|first1=Harold|title=On food and cooking : the science and lore of the kitchen|date=2004|publisher=Scribner|location=New York, NY [u.a.]|isbn=0684800012|edition=Completely rev. and updated.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Myhrvold|first1=Nathan Myhrvold with Chris Young and Maxime Bilet ; photography by Ryan Matthew Smith and Nathan|title=Modernist cuisine : the art and science of cooking|date=2011|publisher=Cooking Lab|location=Bellevue, Wash.|isbn=0982761007|edition=1st}}</ref> [[Flavour]] ([[taste]] and [[Olfaction|smell]]), [[mouthfeel]], [[chemesthesis]], [[astringency]] are all determinants for the sensory evaluation of food, and these characteristics are also related to the chemical properties and the physical texture of the food, and to how the food is transformed in the mouth.<ref name=Mouritsen2016 /> Gastrophysics deals with each of these components and aims at uncovering their mutual relations i.e. how the sensory input relates to the material composition and properties of food, and the absorption in the human body.
Gastrophysics is a scientifically inspired approach to gastronomy, but it is a science in its own right, and not a discipline to service chefs in creating new dishes. Gastrophysics focuses on gaining fundamental scientific insight to gastronomy and understanding universal phenomena, without removing any of the craft, creativity, and art characteristics of cooking.<ref name=MouritsenRisbo2013 />
The relation between gastrophysics and [[gastronomy]], can be seen analogous to the relation between [[astrophysics]] and [[astronomy]].<ref name=Barham2013>{{cite journal|last1=Barham|first1=Peter|title=Physics in the kitchen|journal=Flavour|date=2013|volume=2|issue=1|pages=5|doi=10.1186/2044-7248-2-5}}</ref> [[Astronomers]] observe planets and stars, and describe where they are and how they move. [[Astrophysicists]] explain why the planets and stars are where they are, and how they got there.<ref name=Barham2013 /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Keeler|first1=James E.|title=The Importance of ASTROPHYSIC4L Research and the Relation of Astrophysics to Other Physical Sciences.|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=October 1897|volume=6|pages=271|doi=10.1086/140401|bibcode=1897ApJ.....6..271K}}</ref> In the same way, gastrophysics aims at explaining the universal scientific nature of [[gastronomy]].
== Methodology == Whereas gastrophysics is a relatively new discipline within the physical sciences, the foundation for exploring the kind of soft matter that food is, is already well-established in other areas of modern physics. The methodology of gastrophysics greatly overlaps with e.g. (molecular) [[biophysics]], [[soft matter physics]], [[material physics]], [[physical chemistry]], [[analytical chemistry]] etc. This holds for both experimental, theoretical and phenomenological approaches. Gastrophysics leans on state-of-art technologies both experimentally and computationally.<ref name=Mouritsen2012 />
== History == It is unknown when the term gastrophysics was first coined, but it appears to have been independently proposed as a physics approach to gastronomy in the labs of the physicist [[Nicholas Kurti]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Richards|first1=W. Graham|journal=Nature|date=17 December 1998|volume=396|issue=6712|pages=632–632|doi=10.1038/25257|bibcode=1998Natur.396..632R}}</ref> [[Peter Barham]],<ref name=Barham2013 /> and [https://da.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ole_G._Mouritsen Ole G. Mouritsen].<ref name=Mouritsen2016 /> In order to conceptualise the term “Gastrophysics”, the first international symposium on the topic: “The emerging science of gastrophysics” was held in Copenhagen in 2012, bringing together key actors. One conclusion of the symposium was that gastrophysics could significantly impact gastronomy and tomorrow’s food sciences, and how both develop in the 21st century.<ref name=MouritsenRisbo2013 />

'''Genetic epidemiology''' is the study of the role of [[genetics|genetic]] factors in determining health and disease in families and in populations, and the interplay of such genetic factors with environmental factors. Genetic epidemiology seeks to derive a statistical and quantitative analysis of how genetics work in large groups.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Fundamentals of Genetic Epidemiology|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VC7BAgAAQBAJ|publisher = Oxford University Press|date = 1993-01-01|isbn = 9780195052886|language = en|first = Muin J.|last = Khoury|first2 = Terri H.|last2 = Beaty|first3 = Bernice H.|last3 = Cohen}}</ref>
== Definition == The use of the term ''Genetic epidemiology'' emerged in the mid 1980s as a new scientific field.
In formal language, genetic epidemiology was defined by [[Newton Morton]], one of the pioneers of the field, as "a science which deals with the [[etiology]], distribution, and control of disease in groups of relatives and with inherited causes of disease in populations".<ref>{{cite book | last=Morton |first= N. E. |date=1982 | title=Outline of Genetic Epidemiology |publisher=Karger| location= New York| isbn=3-8055-2269-X }}</ref> It is closely allied to both [[molecular epidemiology]] and [[statistical genetics]], but these overlapping fields each have distinct emphases, societies and journals.<ref name=":0" />
One definition of the field closely follows that of [[Behavioural genetics|behavior genetics]], defining genetic epidemiology as "the scientific discipline that deals with the analysis of the familial distribution of traits, with a view to understanding any possible genetic basis", and that "seeks to understand both the genetic and environmental factors and how they interact to produce various diseases and traits in humans".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Genetic Epidemiology Defined|url = http://www.biostat.wustl.edu/gems/definition.shtml|website = www.biostat.wustl.edu|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> The [[BMJ: British Medical Journal|BMJ]] adopts a similar definition, "Genetic epidemiology is the study of the aetiology, distribution, and control of disease in groups of relatives and of inherited causes of disease in populations."<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Genetic epidemiology|url = http://www.bmj.com/content/320/7244/1257|journal = BMJ|date = 2000-05-06|issn = 0959-8138|pmid = 10797040|pages = 1257–1259|volume = 320|issue = 7244|doi = 10.1136/bmj.320.7244.1257|language = en|first = Jaakko|last = Kaprio|pmc=1117994}}</ref>
== History == As early as the 4th century BC, [[Hippocrates]] suggested in his essay “On Airs, Waters, and Places” that factors such as behavior and environment may play a role in disease. Epidemiology entered a more systematic phase with the work of [[John Graunt]], who in 1662 tried to quantify mortality in London using a statistical approach, tabulating various factors he thought played a role in mortality rates. [[John Snow (physician)|John Snow]] is considered to be the father of epidemiology, and was the first to use statistics to discover and target the cause of disease, specifically of cholera outbreaks in 1854 in London. He investigated the cases of cholera and plotted them onto a map identifying the most likely cause of cholera, which was shown to be contaminated water wells.
=== Modern history === Modern genetics began on the foundation of [[Gregor Mendel]]'s work. Once this became widely known, it spurred a revolution in studies of hereditary throughout the animal kingdom; with studies showing genetic transmission and control over characteristics and traits. As gene variation was shown to affect disease, work began on quantifying factors affecting disease, accelerating in the 20th century. The period since the second world war saw the greatest advancement of the field, with scientists such as [[Newton Morton]] helping form the field of genetic epidemiology as it is known today, with the application of modern genetics to the statistical study of disease, as well as the establishment of large-scale epidemiological studies such as the [[Framingham Heart Study]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = Principles of Epidemiology in Public Health Practice - An Introduction to Applied Epidemiology and Biostatistics|last = |first = |publisher = U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES|year = 2006|isbn = |location = |pages = 1, 7–12}}</ref>
In the 1960s and 1970s, epidemiology played a part in strategies for the worldwide eradication of naturally occurring smallpox.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Epidemiology in the Global Eradication of Smallpox|url = http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/content/1/1/25|journal = International Journal of Epidemiology|date = 1972-03-20|issn = 0300-5771|pmid = 4669176|pages = 25–30|volume = 1|issue = 1|doi = 10.1093/ije/1.1.25|language = en|first = D. A.|last = Henderson}}</ref>
== Fundamentals == Traditionally, the study of the role of genetics in disease progresses through the following study designs, each answering a slightly different question:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dorak.info/epi/genetepi.html |title=Introduction to Genetic Epidemiology | author= M. Tevfik Dorak | date=2008-03-03| accessdate=2008-03-04}}</ref>
* [[Familial aggregation]] studies: Is there a genetic component to the disease, and what are the relative contributions of genes and environment? * [[Genetic segregation|Segregation]] studies: What is the [[dominance relationship|pattern of inheritance]] of the disease (e.g. dominant or recessive)? * [[Genetic linkage|Linkage]] studies: On which part of which [[chromosome]] is the disease gene located? * [[Genetic association|Association]] studies: Which [[allele]] of which gene is associated with the disease?
This traditional approach has proved highly successful in identifying [[monogenic disorder]]s and locating the genes responsible.
More recently, the scope of genetic epidemiology has expanded to include common diseases for which many genes each make a smaller contribution ([[polygenic disorder|polygenic]], [[multifactorial or multigenic disorder]]s). This has developed rapidly in the first decade of the 21st century following completion of the [[Human Genome Project]], as advances in [[genotyping]] technology and associated reductions in cost has made it feasible to conduct large-scale [[genome-wide association study|genome-wide association studies]] that genotype many thousands of [[single nucleotide polymorphism]]s in thousands of individuals. These have led to the discovery of many [[genetic polymorphism]]s that influence the risk of developing many common diseases.
== Approaches == Genetic epidemiological research follows 3 discreet steps, as outlined by M.Tevfik Dorak''':''' # Establishing that there is a genetic component to the disorder. # Establishing the relative size of that genetic effect in relation to other sources of variation in disease risk (environmental effects such as intrauterine environment, physical and chemical effects as well as behavioral and social aspects). # Identifying the gene(s) responsible for the genetic component. These research methodologies can be assessed through either family or population studies.<ref>{{Cite web|title = INTRODUCTION TO GENETIC EPIDEMIOLOGY [M.Tevfik DORAK]|url = http://www.dorak.info/epi/genetepi.html|website = www.dorak.info|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Epigenetics]] * [[Genetic disorder]] * [[Mendelian randomization]] * [[Molecular epidemiology]] * [[Mutation]] * [[Population genetics]] * [[Hardy–Weinberg principle]] * [[Population groups in biomedicine]]

'''Gerhard Fischer''' (20 September 1921 – 3 July 2006) was a German diplomat, ambassador and humanitarian who received the 1997 [[Gandhi Peace Prize]] in recognition of his work for [[leprosy]] and [[Poliomyelitis|polio]]-afflicted patients in India.<ref name="Rotarian 1999-02" />
Born in [[Oslo]], Fischer grew up in China and studied medicine at [[Beijing Medical University]], where he gained experience as a volunteer with leprosy patients. When he was forced to abandon the course by the Japanese occupation, he travelled to Germany intending to study medicine there, but instead was obliged to fight in [[World War II]], then was held as a [[Prisoner of war|POW]] in France.<ref name="Chennai Online" /> After the war, he obtained a law degree and entered the German diplomatic service.
While at the German consulate in [[Madras]], he helped a German doctor to establish a leprosy treatment and rehabilitation centre at Chettipatty. He was also instrumental in setting up the [[Indian Institute of Technology Madras|Indian Institute of Technology]] in Madras,<ref name="Chennai Online" /> which was founded with financial and technical support from the [[West Germany|West German]] government.<ref name="IITM History" /> He later became ambassador to Malaysia, Ireland, Netherlands, and finally Switzerland.
He resigned from the diplomatic service in order to devote himself full-time to the support of leprosy and polio patients in India. Fischer regarded rehabilitation as the most important aspect of his work, and emphasised the need for attitudes to leprosy to change. His work was recognised by the Indian government with the award of the Gandhi Peace Prize. Fischer used the money from the prize to set up a foundation for his humanitarian work.
== Early life and education == Fischer was born in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]], the elder son of a Norwegian mother and a German father, [[Martin Fischer (sinologist)|Martin Fischer]].<ref name="Muthiah 2006-10-16" /> When he was about 3 years old, his family moved to China, where his father was a [[sinologist]]. As a boy, Fischer had always wanted to be a doctor. He started to study medicine at [[Beijing Medical University]], but was forced to abandon the course when the University was closed by the [[Second Sino-Japanese War|Japanese occupation]]. So he decided to travel—via [[Siberia]]—to Germany, intending to study medicine there, but was instead compelled to fight in [[World War II|"another huge war"]], a situation he regarded as a "trap".<ref name="rediff - part 1" /> He spent five years fighting in the war, mainly on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]], followed by two years nine months as a prisoner of war. Destitute after the war, studying medicine was out of the question. He worked as a truck driver and various other jobs, and after three years had saved enough money to study again.<ref name="rediff - part 2" /> He entered a legal [[crammer]], and in one year obtained a law degree, a course that normally requires four years' study.
While studying medicine in Beijing, he volunteered to look after leprosy patients (an opportunity offered to all medical students there, in the days before [[Alexander Fleming|Fleming]] and modern [[antibiotics]]). From then on, he wanted to care for leprosy patients.<ref name="rediff - part 2" />
== Diplomatic career == With a law degree in hand, he decided to join the German foreign service, as that would take him overseas.<ref name="rediff - part 2" /> In 1952–1953 he completed his training for the higher diplomatic and consular service in [[Speyer]], Rhineland-Palatinate, passing the final exam in 1953. He began his career at the German [[legation]] in [[Addis Ababa]], [[Ethiopia]], followed by a posting to the consulate in Hong Kong from 1957 to 1960, when he took over the consulate in Madras. In 1963 he was promoted to [[Consul (representative)|Consul]], and in 1964 returned to the [[Bonn]] headquarters of the Foreign Office (''[[Auswärtiges Amt]]''). He was appointed to the rank of Councillor (''Vortragender Legationsrat'') in 1966 and from 1968 headed a political department there, becoming a First Councillor (''Vortragender Legationsrat Erster Klasse'') shortly afterwards.<ref name="Munzinger" />
His first appointment as Ambassador came in 1970, when he represented [[West Germany]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia. In March 1974 he was promoted to lead a large department in the Foreign Office dealing with Asia and Latin America. His second ambassadorial appointment came in July 1977, when he was sent to [[Dublin]], followed by further appointments to [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]] (early 1980) and [[Bern]], [[Switzerland]] (mid-1983). In December 1985, only six months before reaching his normal retirement age, he resigned from the diplomatic service in order to devote more time to leprosy paients in India.<ref name="Munzinger" />
Fischer later said that taking a European posting, after his service in [[Vietnam]], [[Malaysia]] and [[India]] was a "mistake".<ref name="rediff - part 2" />
== Work with leprosy and polio patients == As well as volunteering with leprosy patients during his medical training in Beijing, Fischer had also looked after leprosy patients in his free time at [[Addis Ababa]] and Hong Kong.<ref name="Munzinger" />
Fischer's work with leprosy patients in India began in 1960, when he was German [[Consul-General]] in Madras (now [[Chennai]]), in [[Tamil Nadu]]. A German doctor, [[Elizabeth Vomstein]], had asked for his help in obtaining a work permit so that she could work with a French nun she had heard of who was helping leprosy patients in Chettipatty, near [[Salem, Tamil Nadu|Salem]]. Fischer successfully helped her get the work permit, then drove with her to Chettipatty. Fischer remained in post in Tamil Nadu for four years, during which time he regularly visited Vomstein's station in Chettipatty, which she slowly built up to what he regarded as a "model station".<ref name="rediff - part 3" />
After resigning from the diplomatic service in 1985, Fischer regularly spent six months each year in India, and six months in the summer with his wife at their small farm near [[Chiemsee]], a lake in [[Bavaria]]. His wife, Ann, ran the administration, fund-raising and publicity for Fischer's work. They had decided not to have "an administration", so Fischer and his wife did everything on their own. Fischer said that his wife "deserves half this prize" (the Gandhi Peace Prize).<ref name="rediff - part 1" />
Until 1991 he worked with Elizabeth Vomstein at her station in Chettipatty. He found her "very, very difficult", but said, "If she wasn't that type, she wouldn't have lasted 38 years."<ref name="rediff - part 3" /> By 1991, he had had enough, and started out on his own.<ref name="rediff - part 3" /> He had already built his own leprosy station in the foothills of the [[Himalayas]], and in the following years he established health centres, workshops and schools throughout India, building wells and latrines, and obtaining Jeeps, minibuses and other supplies. He was also involved with projects in [[Nepal]] and [[Vietnam]].<ref name="Munzinger" />
Fischer regarded curing leprosy as the easy part, with modern medicines, good treatment and good food.<ref name="rediff - part 3" /> Much more important to Fischer was rehabilitation,<ref name="heart - The Hindu" /> which he regarded as his primary aim. He recognised that patients with missing legs or fingers would have no chance of surviving outside his stations. So he trained them in skills to earn a living, such as making [[chappal]]s, table cloths, mats, bed covers, beautiful carpets, and so on. He hoped to reach a position where his stations would no longer need donations, but could survive on their production.<ref name="rediff - part 3" />
=== Polio === Fischer's leprosy treatment, rehabilitation and vocational training centres also cared for polio victims. By 2005, new polio cases had been greatly reduced, thanks to vaccination and joint efforts between the Indian government and NGOs. As a result, Fischer's centres were able to take on additional responsibilities in other areas. But Fischer stressed the need for medical practitioners in the primary health centres to maintain a watch over polio and leprosy, and to be trained in recognising the symptoms.<ref name="Fischer back - The Hindu" /><ref name="marathon - The Hindu" />
=== Attitudes to leprosy === Fischer insisted that his patients should never be called "lepers", but rather "leprosy patients". Although he stated that he believed in ''[[karma]]'', he condemned the consequent fatalism of, and inaction towards, leprosy patients in India, saying "It is not their fault. It is the bloody bug that caught them." He felt that they were outcasts who needed attention. In his Gandhi peace prize acceptance speech at the [[Rashtrapati Bhavan]], he said, "Don't treat us like outcasts. Don't treat us like the forgotten. We are also here in this country although you don't care about us."<ref name="rediff - part 2" /> Many visitors to his stations couldn't face the physically horrible nature of the disease, but Fischer said that it was far worse mentally to be an outcast from one's family and community. He said, "If you work in a leprosy community, the mental anguish is supreme and it is no different for me."<ref name="rediff - part 3" />
Fischer would touch all his patients, saying ''Nalla thane irukku'' ("You are all right"). He never wore a mask or gloves, as he thought the "human side" of his work was very important, that there should be no barriers, and that there was "no difference between us, two human beings".<ref name="rediff - part 3" />
=== "Leprosy is curable" === Fischer said, "I need publicity. I want to beat the drum, Leprosy is curable. Come and watch. Forget about the stigma. Forget about treating them as outcasts. Here I am constantly shouting to make the community aware and this Prize gives me a chance to focus the attention on 'us' who are forgotten."<ref name="rediff - part 3" />
=== Importance of early treatment === Fischer always emphasised the importance of early treatment. Patients were reluctant to admit that they might have leprosy, because of the fear of being thrown out of their family and community. Fischer said, "If you get early treatment, nobody can see that you ever had leprosy. This message is very important."<ref name="rediff - part 3" />
== Gandhi peace prize == Fischer received the Indian government's [[Gandhi Peace Prize]] for 1997 in New Delhi on 5 January 1998 from the President of India, [[K. R. Narayanan]]. The selection committee was unanimous in its decision to award the prize to Fischer.<ref name="Rotarian 1999-02" /> The prize carried an award of 10 million [[Indian rupee|rupees]], which Fischer used to set up a foundation for his humanitarian work.<ref name="Munzinger" /> In his acceptance speech at the [[Rashtrapati Bhavan]], the official residence of the [[President of India]], Fischer said, "It is not enough to have compassion, ''[[Daya (Sikhism)|daya]]'', ''[[karuṇā]]'', and pity for the leprosy patients. We lepers, we don't care about compassion. We want action."<ref name="rediff - part 3" /> Referring to the government slogan of "eradicating leprosy by 2000", he said that his speech made people such as [[Sonia Gandhi]], who were sitting in the front of the audience, very uncomfortable.<ref name="rediff - part 3" />
== Death == Fischer died in [[Copenhagen]] on 3 July 2006, aged 84 years.<ref name="Munzinger" /> On 8 July 2006, a silent procession was organised at [[Ayikudi]] as a mark of respect.<ref name="tributes - The Hindu" /> N.S. Rao, a former colleague of Fischer at the German consulate in Madras, said that Fischer "applied a missionary zeal to anything he put his mind to. He and his wife were a perfect two-people team and worked all over the country with tremendous energy and indefatigable enthusiasm. After his wife's death, he had been carrying on his social work relentlessly."<ref name="Obit - The Hindu" /> Rao added that Fischer's daughter, Karen Fischer Koch, carried on her father's work after his death.<ref name="Muthiah 2006-10-16" />

origin|symbol]] used to raise awareness for HELLP | pronounce = | synonyms = | symptoms = Feeling tired, retaining fluid, [[headache]], nausea, upper [[abdominal pain]], blurry vision, [[seizures]]<ref name=GARD2018/> | complications = [[Disseminated intravascular coagulation]] (DIC), [[placental abruption]], [[kidney failure]], [[pulmonary edema]]<ref name=GARD2018/> | onset = Last 3 months of pregnancy or shortly after [[childbirth]]<ref name=GARD2018/> | duration = | types = Complete, incomplete<ref name=Har2009/> | causes = Unknown<ref name=GARD2018/> | risks = [[Preeclampsia]], [[eclampsia]], previously having HELLP, mother older than 25 years, [[White people|white]]<ref name=GARD2018/> | diagnosis = Blood tests<ref name=Har2009/> | differential = [[Viral hepatitis]], [[thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura]], [[cholangitis]], [[hemolytic uremic syndrome]]<ref name=Har2009/> | prevention = | treatment = Delivery of the baby as soon as possible, management of blood pressure<ref name=GARD2018/><ref name=Har2009/> | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = ~0.7% of pregnancies<ref name=Har2009/> | deaths = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''HELLP syndrome''' is a [[complication of pregnancy]] characterized by [[hemolysis|'''h'''emolysis]], [[elevated liver enzymes|'''e'''levated '''l'''iver enzymes]], and a [[thrombocytopenia|'''l'''ow '''p'''latelet count]].<ref name=GARD2018>{{cite web |title=HELLP syndrome |url=https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/8528/hellp-syndrome |website=Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD) – an NCATS Program |accessdate=5 October 2018 |language=en |date=2018}}</ref> It usually begins during the last three months of pregnancy or shortly after [[childbirth]].<ref name=GARD2018/> Symptoms may include feeling tired, retaining fluid, headache, nausea, upper right [[abdominal pain]], blurry vision, [[nosebleed]]s, and [[seizures]].<ref name=GARD2018/> Complications may include [[disseminated intravascular coagulation]] (DIC), [[placental abruption]], and [[kidney failure]].<ref name=GARD2018/>
<!-- Cause and diagnosis --> The cause is unknown.<ref name=GARD2018/> Usually it occurs in association with [[preeclampsia]] or [[eclampsia]].<ref name=GARD2018/> Other risk factors include previously having the syndrome, a mother older than 25 years, and being [[White people|white]].<ref name=GARD2018/> Diagnosis is generally based on blood tests finding signs of red blood cell break down ([[Lactate dehydrogenase|LDH]] greater than 600 U/L), an [[Aspartate transaminase|AST]] greater than 70 U/L, and platelets of less than 100x10<sup>9</sup>/L.<ref name=Har2009/> If not all the criteria are present the condition is incomplete.<ref name=Har2009/>
<!-- Treatment --> Treatment generally involves delivery of the baby as soon as possible.<ref name=GARD2018/> This is particularly true if the pregnancy is beyond 34 weeks of [[gestation]].<ref name=Har2009/> Medications may be used to decrease blood pressure and [[blood transfusion]]s may be required.<ref name=GARD2018/> [[Corticosteroids]] may be used to speed development of the babies lungs, if it is early in pregnancy.<ref name=Har2009/>
<!-- Epidemiology and history --> HELLP syndrome occurs in about 0.7% of pregnancies and affects about 15% of women with eclampsia or severe preeclampsia.<ref name=Mer2018>{{cite web |title=Preeclampsia and Eclampsia |url=https://www.merckmanuals.com/home/women-s-health-issues/complications-of-pregnancy/preeclampsia-and-eclampsia#v813330 |website=Merck Manuals Consumer Version |accessdate=5 October 2018 |date=March 2018}}</ref><ref name=Har2009>{{cite journal | vauthors=Haram K, Svendsen E, and Abildgaard U| title=The HELLP syndrome: clinical issues and management. A Review | journal=BMC Pregnancy Childbirth | volume =9 | pages = 8 | date = February 2009 | pmc = 2654858 | pmid= 19245695 | doi=10.1186/1471-2393-9-8 }}</ref> Death of the mother is uncommon.<ref name=GARD2018/> Outcomes in the baby are generally related to how [[Premature birth|premature]] they are at birth.<ref name=GARD2018/> The syndrome was first named in 1982.<ref name=Har2009/>
==Signs and symptoms== The first signs of HELLP start appearing midway through the [[third trimester]], though the signs can appear in earlier and later stages.<ref name="ref5" /> Symptoms vary in severity and between individuals and are commonly mistaken with normal pregnancy symptoms, especially if they are not severe.<ref name="ref26">{{cite journal | vauthors=Visser W, Wallenburg HC | title=Temporising management of severe pre-eclampsia with and without the HELLP syndrome | journal=Br J Obstet Gynaecol | volume =102 | issue = 2 | pages = 111–7 | date = February 1995 | pmid= 7756201}}</ref>
HELLP syndrome patients suffer from general discomfort followed by severe [[epigastric pain]] or right upper abdominal quadrant pain, accompanied by [[nausea]], [[vomiting]], [[backache]], anaemia, and [[hypertension]]. Some patients may also suffer from a [[headache]] and visual issues. These symptoms may also become more severe at night time.<ref name="ref4" /><ref name="ref17" /><ref name="ref27">{{cite journal | vauthors=Sibai BM| title=he HELLP syndrome (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets): much ado about nothing? | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =162 | issue = 2 | pages = 311–6| date = February 1990 | pmid= 2309811}}</ref><ref name="ref28">{{cite journal | vauthors=Weinstein L| title=It has been a great ride: The history of HELLP syndrome | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =193 | issue = 3 Pt 1 | pages = 860–3 | date = September 2005 | pmid= 16150288 | doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2005.06.058}}</ref><ref name="ref29">{{cite journal | vauthors=Aarnoudse JG, Houthoff HJ, Weits J, Vellenga E, Huisjes HJ| title=A syndrome of liver damage and intravascular coagulation in the last trimester of normotensive pregnancy. A clinical and histopathological study | journal=Br J Obstet Gynaecol | volume =93 | issue = 2 | pages = 145–55| date = February 1986 | pmid= 3511956}}</ref><ref name="ref30">{{cite journal | vauthors=Araujo AC, Leao MD, Nobrega MH, Bezerra PF, Pereira FV, Dantas EM, Azevedo GD, Jeronimo SM| title=Characteristics and treatment of hepatic rupture caused by HELLP syndrome | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =1995 | issue = 1 | pages = 129–33 | date = July 2006 | pmid= 16579935 | doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2006.01.016}}</ref> As the condition progresses and worsens, a spontaneous [[hematoma]] occurs following the rupture of the liver capsule, which occurs more frequently in the right lobe. The presence of any combinations of these symptoms, subcapsular liver hematoma in particular, warrants an immediate check-up due to the high morbidity and mortality rates of this condition.<ref name="ref21">{{cite journal | vauthors=Strand S, Strand D, Seufert R, Mann A, Lotz J, Blessing M, Lahn M, Wunsch A, Broering DC, Hahn U, Grischke EM, Rogiers X, Otto G, Gores GJ, Galle PR | title=Placenta-derived CD95 ligand causes liver damage in hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count syndrome | journal=Gastroenterology | volume =126 | issue = 3 | pages = 849–58 | date = March 2004 | pmid= 14988839}}</ref><ref name="ref31">{{cite journal | vauthors=Rinehart BK, Terrone DA, Magann EF, Martin RW, May WL, Martin JN Jr| title=Preeclampsia-associated hepatic hemorrhage and rupture: mode of management related to maternal and perinatal outcome | journal= Obstet Gynecol Surv | volume =54 | issue = 3 | pages = 196–202 | date = March 1996 | pmid= 10071839}}</ref><ref name="ref32">{{cite journal | vauthors=Wicke C, Pereira PL, Neeser E, Flesch I, Rodegerdts EA, Becker HD| title=Subcapsular liver hematoma in HELLP syndrome: Evaluation of diagnostic and therapeutic options--a unicenter study | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =190 | issue = 1 | pages = 106–12 | date = January 2004 | pmid= 14749644 | doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2003.08.029}}</ref>
==Risk factors== Elevated [[body mass index]] (BMI) and [[metabolic disorders]], as well as, antiphospholipid-antibody syndrome ([[Antiphospholipid syndrome|APLS]]) significantly increase the risk of HELLP syndrome in all female patients. Females who have had or are related to a female with previous HELLP syndrome complications tend to be at a higher risk in all their subsequent pregnancies.<ref name="ref18" /><ref name="ref33">{{cite journal | vauthors=Habli M, Eftekhari N, Wiebracht E, Bombrys A, Khabbaz M, How H, Sibai B| title=Long-term maternal and subsequent pregnancy outcomes 5 years after hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets (HELLP) syndrome | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =201 | issue = 4 | pages = 385 e1–5 | date = October 2009 | pmid= 19716544 | doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2009.06.033}}</ref><ref name="ref34">{{cite journal | vauthors=Hupuczi P, Rigo B, Sziller I, Szabo G, Szigeti Z, Papp Z| title=Follow-up analysis of pregnancies complicated by HELLP syndrome | journal=Fetal Diagn Ther | volume =21 | issue = 6 | pages = 519–22 | date = 2006 | pmid= 16969007 | doi=10.1159/000095665}}</ref>
The risk of HELLP syndrome is not conclusively associated with a specific genetic variation, but it is likely that a combination of genetic variations, such as ''[[Fas receptor|FAS]]'' gene, ''[[VEGF]]'' gene, ''[[glucocorticoid receptor]]'' gene and the ''tol-like receptor'' gene, increase the risk.<ref name="ref33" /><ref name="ref35">{{cite journal | vauthors=Sziller I, Hupuczi P, Normand N, Halmos A, Papp Z, Witkin SS| title=Fas (TNFRSF6) gene polymorphism in pregnant women with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets and in their neonates | journal=Obstet Gynecol | volume =107 | issue = 3 | pages = 582–7| date = March 2009 | pmid= 16507928 | doi=10.1097/01.AOG.0000195824.51919.81}}</ref><ref name="ref36">{{cite journal | vauthors=Nagy B, Savli H, Molvarec A, Varkonyi T, Rigo B, Hupuczi P, Rigo J Jr| title=Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) polymorphisms in HELLP syndrome patients determined by quantitative real-time PCR and melting curve analyses | journal=Clin Chim Acta | volume =389 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 126–31 | date = 2006 | pmid= 18167313 | doi=10.1016/j.cca.2007.12.003}}</ref><ref name="ref37">{{cite journal | vauthors=Bertalan R, Patocs A, Nagy B, Derzsy Z, Gullai N, Szappanos A | title=Overrepresentation of BclI polymorphism of the glucocorticoid receptor gene in pregnant women with HELLP syndrome | journal=Clin Chim Acta | volume =405 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 148–52 | date = July 2009 | pmid= 19336230 | doi=10.1016/j.cca.2009.03.046}}</ref><ref name="ref38">{{cite journal | vauthors=van Rijn BB, Franx A, Steegers EA, de Groot CJ, Bertina RM, Pasterkamp G | title=Maternal TLR4 and NOD2 gene variants, pro-inflammatory phenotype and susceptibility to early-onset preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome | journal=PLoS One | volume =3 | issue = 4 | pages = e1865 | date = April 2008 | pmid= 18382655 | pmc=2270909 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0001865}}</ref>
==Pathophysiology== The pathophysiology is still unclear and an exact cause is yet to be found. However, it shares a common mechanism, which is [[endothelial cell]] injury, with other conditions, such as [[acute renal failure]] and [[thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura]].<ref name="ref9">{{cite journal | vauthors=Geary M | title=The HELLP syndrome | journal=Br J Obstet Gynaecol | volume =104 | issue = 8 | pages = 877–91 | date = August 1997 | pmid=9255078 }}</ref><ref name="ref10">{{cite journal | vauthors=Sibai BM, Kustermann L, Velasco J| title=DCurrent understanding of severe preeclampsia, pregnancy-associated hemolytic uremic syndrome, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet syndrome, and postpartum acute renal failure: different clinical syndromes or just different names? | journal=Curr Opin Nephrol Hypertens | volume =3 | issue = 4 | pages = 436–45 | date = July 1994 | pmid=8076148}}</ref> Increasing the understanding of HELLP syndrome’s pathophysiology will enhance diagnostic accuracy, especially in the early stages. This will lead to advancements in the prevention, management, and treatment of the condition, which will increase the likelihood of both maternal and fetal survival and recovery.<ref name="ref5" /><ref name="ref11">{{cite journal | vauthors=Benedetto C, Marozio L, Tancredi A,Picardo E,Nardolillo P, Tavella AM, Salton L| title=Biochemistry of HELLP syndrome | journal=Adv Clin Chem | volume =53| pages = 85–104 | date = 2011 | pmid=21404915}}</ref>
===Inflammation and coagulation=== As a result of endothelial cell injury, a cascade of pathological reactions manifests and become increasingly severe and even fatal as signs and symptoms progress. Following endothelial injury, vasospasms and platelet activation occur alongside the decreased release of the [[endothelium-derived relaxing factor]] and increased the release of [[von Willebrand factor]] ([[Von Willebrand factor|vWF]]), leading to general activation of the [[coagulation]] cascade and [[inflammation]]. Placental components, such as inflammatory [[cytokines]] and [[syncytiotrophoblast]] particles interact with the maternal immune system and endothelial cells, further promoting coagulation and inflammation.<ref name="ref12">{{cite journal | vauthors=Gardiner C, Tannetta DS, Simms CA, Harrison P, Redman CW, Sargent IL| title=Syncytiotrophoblast microvesicles released from pre-eclampsia placentae exhibit increased tissue factor activity | journal=PLoS One | volume =6 | issue = 10 | pages = e26313 | date = 2011 | pmid= 22022598 | pmc=3194796 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0026313}}</ref><ref name="ref13">{{cite journal | vauthors=Hulstein JJ, van Runnard Heimel PJ, Franx A, Lenting PJ, Bruinse HW, Silence K, de Groot PG, Fijnheer R| title=Acute activation of the endothelium results in increased levels of active von Willebrand factor in hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes and low platelets (HELLP) syndrome | journal=PLoS One | volume =4 | issue = 12 | pages = 2569–75 | date = December 2006| pmid= 16968329 | doi=10.1111/j.1538-7836.2006.02205.x}}</ref> These interactions also elevate leukocyte numbers and interleukin concentrations, as well as increase complement activity.<ref name="ref14">{{cite journal | vauthors=Terrone DA, Rinehart BK, May WL, Moore A, Magann EF, Martin JN Jr| title=SLeukocytosis is proportional to HELLP syndrome severity: evidence for an inflammatory form of preeclampsia | journal=South Med J | volume =93 | issue = 8 | pages = 768–71 | date = August 2000 | pmid= 10963506}}</ref><ref name="ref15">{{cite journal | vauthors=Haeger M, Unander M, Norder-Hansson B, Tylman M, Bengtsson A | title=Complement, neutrophil, and macrophage activation in women with severe preeclampsia and the syndrome of hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count | journal=Obstet Gynecol | volume =79 | issue = 1 | pages = 19–26 | date = January 1992 | pmid= 1727579}}</ref>
===Low platelet count=== vWF degradation in HELLP syndrome is inhibited due to decreased levels of degrading proteins, leading to an increased exposure of [[platelets]] to vWF. As a result, [[thrombotic microangiopathies]] develop and lead to [[thrombocytopenia]].<ref name="ref16">{{cite journal | vauthors=Lattuada A, Rossi E, Calzarossa C, Candolfi R, Mannucci PM | title=Mild to moderate reduction of a von Willebrand factor cleaving protease (ADAMTS-13) in pregnant women with HELLP microangiopathic syndrome | journal=Haematologica | volume =88 | issue = 9 | pages = 1029–34 | date = September 2003 | pmid= 12969811}}</ref>
===Blood breakdown=== As a result of the high number of angiopathies, the [[erythrocytes]] fragment as they pass through the blood vessels with damaged endothelium and large [[fibrin]] networks, leading to macroangiopathic [[haemolytic anaemia]]. As a consequence of hemolysis, [[lactic acid dehydrogenase]] (LDH) and [[hemoglobin]] are released, with the latter binding to serum [[bilirubin]] or [[haptoglobin]].<ref name="ref17">{{cite journal | vauthors=Sibai BM | title=Diagnosis, controversies, and management of the syndrome of hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count | journal=Obstet Gynecol | volume =103 | issue = 5 Pt 1 | pages = 981–91 | date = May 2004 | pmid= 15121574| doi= 10.1097/01.AOG.0000126245.35811.2a}}</ref><ref name="ref18">{{cite journal | vauthors=Lachmeijer AM, Arngrimsson R, Bastiaans EJ, Frigge ML, Pals G, Sigurdardottir S, Stefansson H, Palsson B, Nicolae D, Kong A, Aarnoudse JG, Gulcher JR, Dekker GA, ten Kate LP, Stefansson K | title=A genome-wide scan for preeclampsia in the Netherlands | journal=Eur J Hum Genet | volume =9 | issue = 10 | pages = 758–64 | date = October 2001 | pmid= 11781687 | doi=10.1038/sj.ejhg.5200706}}</ref>
===Liver=== During the coagulation cascade, fibrin is deposited in the liver and leads to hepatic sinusoidal obstruction and [[vascular congestion]], which increase intrahepatic pressure. Placenta-derived FasL ([[CD95L]]), which is toxic to human [[hepatocytes]], leads to hepatocyte apoptosis and necrosis by inducing the expression of [[TNFα]] and results in the release of liver enzymes. Hepatic damages are worsened by the disrupted portal and total hepatic blood flow that result as a consequence of the microangiopathies. Collectively, widespread endothelial dysfunction and hepatocellular damage result in global hepatic dysfunction often leading to liver [[necrosis]], haemorrhages, and capsular rupture.<ref name="ref1">{{cite journal | vauthors=Weinstein L | title=Syndrome of hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count: a severe consequence of hypertension in pregnancy | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =142 | issue = 2 | pages = 159–67 | date = January 1982 | pmid = 7055180 }}</ref><ref name="ref19">{{cite journal | vauthors=Norwitz ER, Hsu CD, Repke JT | title=Acute complications of preeclampsia | journal=Clin Obstet Gynecol | volume =45 | issue = 2 | pages = 308–29 | date = June 2002 | pmid= 12048392}}</ref><ref name="ref20">{{cite journal|vauthors=Stevenson JT, Graham DJ |title=Hepatic hemorrhage and the HELLP syndrome: a surgeon's perspective |journal=Am Surg |volume=61 |issue=9 |pages=756–60 |date=September 1995 |pmid=7661469}}</ref>
==Diagnosis == ===Diagnosis=== Early and accurate diagnosis, which relies on laboratory tests and imaging exams, is essential for treatment and management and significantly reduces the morbidity rate. However, diagnosis of the syndrome is challenging, especially due to the variability in the signs and symptoms and the lack of consensus amongst healthcare professionals. Similarities to other conditions, as well as normal pregnancy features, commonly lead to misdiagnosed cases or more often, delayed diagnosis.<ref name="ref5" /><ref name="ref11" />
There is a general consensus regarding the main three diagnostic criteria of HELLP syndrome, which include [[hepatic dysfunction]], thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia in patients suspected to have preeclampsia. * A [[blood smear]] will often exhibit abnormalities, such as [[schistocytes]], bur cells, and [[helmet cells]], which indicate erythrocyte damage. * Thrombocytopenia, which is the earliest [[coagulopathy]] present in all HELLP syndrome patients, is indicated by low platelet count (below 100 x 109 L-1) or by testing the levels of fibrin metabolites and [[antithrombin III]]. * Elevated serum levels of certain proteins, in particular, LDH, [[alanine transaminase]] (ALT) and [[aspartate transaminase]] (AST), are indicative of hepatic dysfunction. Extremely high serum levels of these proteins, specifically LDH levels > 1,400 IU/L, AST levels > 150 IU/L and ALT levels > 100 IU/L, significantly elevate the risk of maternal mortality.<ref name="ref1" /><ref name=Har2009 /><ref name="ref17" /><ref name="ref27" /><ref name="ref9" /><ref name="ref19" /><ref name="ref39">{{cite journal | vauthors=Martin JN Jr, Rinehart BK, May WL, Magann EF, Terrone DA, Blake PG | title=The spectrum of severe preeclampsia: comparative analysis by HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzyme levels, and low platelet count) syndrome classification | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =180 | issue = 6 Pt 1 | pages = 1373–84 | date = June 1999 | pmid= 10368474}}</ref><ref name="ref40">{{cite journal | vauthors=Martin JN Jr, Rose CH, Briery CM | title=Understanding and managing HELLP syndrome: the integral role of aggressive glucocorticoids for mother and child | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =195 | issue = 4 | pages = 914–34 | date = October 2006 | pmid= 16631593 | doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2005.08.044}}</ref><ref name="ref41">{{cite journal | vauthors=Martin JN Jr, Blake PG, Perry KG, Jr, McCaul JF, Hess LW, Martin RW | title=The natural history of HELLP syndrome: patterns of disease progression and regression | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =164 | issue = 6 Pt 1 | pages = 1500–9; discussion 1509–13 | date = June 1992 | pmid= 2048596}}</ref><ref name="ref42">{{cite journal | vauthors=Catanzarite VA, Steinberg SM, Mosley CA, Landers CF, Cousins LM, Schneider JM | title=Severe preeclampsia with fulminant and extreme elevation of aspartate aminotransferase and lactate dehydrogenase levels: high risk for maternal death | journal=Am J Perinatol | volume =12 | issue = 5 | pages = 310–3 | date = September 1995 | pmid= 8540929 | doi=10.1055/s-2007-994482}}</ref>
A number of other, but less conclusive, clinical diagnostic criteria are also used in diagnosis alongside the main clinical diagnostic criteria for HELLP syndrome. * ''De novo'' manifestation of hypertension with [[systolic pressure]] and [[diastolic]] pressure above 160mmHg and 110 mmHg, respectively. * [[Proteinuria]], [[leucocytosis]] and elevated [[uric acid]] concentrations > 7.8 mg. * Decreased serum haptoglobin and haemoglobin levels. * Increased serum bilirubin levels and visual disturbances.<ref name="ref43">{{cite journal | vauthors=Roberts JM, Taylor RN, Musci TJ, Rodgers GM, Hubel CA, McLaughlin MK | title=Preeclampsia: an endothelial cell disorder | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =161 | issue = 5 | pages = 1200–4 | date = November 1989 | pmid= 2589440}}</ref><ref name="ref44">{{cite journal | vauthors=Sibai BM | title=Treatment of hypertension in pregnant women | journal=N Engl J Med | volume =335 | issue = 45 | pages = 257–65 | date = July 1996 | pmid= 8657243 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199607253350407}}</ref>
Imaging tests, such as [[ultrasound]], [[tomography]] or [[magnetic resonance imaging]] ([[MRI]]), are instrumental in the correct diagnosis of HELLP syndrome in patients with suspected liver dysfunction. Unurgent cases must undergo MRI, but laboratory tests, such as glucose determination, are more encouraged in mild cases of HELLP syndrome.<ref name="ref1" /><ref name="ref4" /><ref name="ref45">{{cite journal | vauthors=Weinstein L | title=Preeclampsia/eclampsia with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and thrombocytopenia | journal=Obstet Gynecol | volume =66 | issue = 5 | pages = 657–60 | date = November 1985 | pmid= 4058824}}</ref>
===Classification=== A classification system, which was developed in [[Mississippi]], measures the severity of the syndrome using the lowest observed platelet count in the patients alongside the appearance of the other two main clinical criteria. Class I is the most severe, with a relatively high risk of morbidity and mortality, compared to the other two classes.<ref name="ref46">{{cite journal | vauthors=Martin JN Jr, Blake PG, Lowry SL, Perry KG Jr, Files JC, Morrison JC| title=Pregnancy complicated by preeclampsia-eclampsia with the syndrome of hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count: how rapid is postpartum recovery?| journal=Obstet Gynecol | volume =76 | issue = 5 Pt 1 | pages = 737–41| date = November 1990 | pmid= 2216215}}</ref> * Class I HELLP syndrome is characterised by a platelet count below 50,000/µL. * Class II HELLP syndrome is characterised by a platelet count of 50,000-100,000/µL. * Class III HELLP syndrome is characterised by a platelet count of 100,000-150,000/µL.
Another classification system, introduced in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], categorises HELLP syndrome based on its expression. * Partial expression of the condition is characterised by the manifestation of one or two of the main diagnostic criteria. * The complete expression of the condition is characterised by the manifestation of all three main diagnostic criteria.<ref name="ref47">{{cite journal | vauthors=Audibert F, Friedman SA, Frangieh AY, Sibai BM | title=Clinical utility of strict diagnostic criteria for the HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets) syndrome | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =175 | issue =2 | pages = 460–4 | date = August 1996 | pmid= 8765269}}</ref>
==Treatment== The only current recommended and most effective treatment is delivery of the baby, as the signs and symptoms diminish and gradually disappear following the delivery of the [[placenta]]. Prompt delivery is the only viable option in cases with multiorgan dysfunction or [[multiorgan failure]], haemorrhage and considerable danger to the fetus. Certain medications are also used to target and alleviate specific symptoms.<ref name="ref1" /><ref name=Har2009 /><ref name="ref4" /><ref name="ref48">{{cite journal | vauthors=Haddad B, Barton JR, Livingston JC, Chahine R, Sibai BM | title=Risk factors for adverse maternal outcomes among women with HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count) syndrome | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =183 | issue =2 | pages =444–8 | date = August 2000 | pmid= 10942484 | doi=10.1067/mob.2000.105915}}</ref><ref name="ref49">{{cite journal | vauthors=Rath W, Loos W, Kuhn W, Graeff H| title=The importance of early laboratory screening methods for maternal and fetal outcome in cases of HELLP syndrome | journal=Eur J Obstet Gynecol Reprod Biol | volume =36 | issue =1–2 | pages = 43–51 | date = August 1990 | pmid= 2365128}}</ref>
[[Corticosteroids]] are of unclear benefit, though there is tentative evidence that they can increase the mother's platelet count.<ref name=Wou2010>{{cite journal |last1=Woudstra |first1=DM |last2=Chandra |first2=S |last3=Hofmeyr |first3=GJ |last4=Dowswell |first4=T |title=Corticosteroids for HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets) syndrome in pregnancy. |journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews |date=8 September 2010 |issue=9 |pages=CD008148 |doi=10.1002/14651858.CD008148.pub2 |pmid=20824872|pmc=4171033 }}</ref><ref name="ref56">{{cite journal | vauthors=Aloizos S, Seretis C, Liakos N, Aravosita P, Mystakelli C, Kanna E, Gourgiotis | title=HELLP syndrome: understanding and management of a pregnancy-specific disease | journal=J Obstet Gynaecol | volume =33 | issue =4 | pages =331–7| date = May 2013 | pmid=23654309 | doi=10.3109/01443615.2013.775231}}</ref>
==Prognosis== With treatment, maternal mortality is about 1 percent, although complications such as [[placental abruption]], [[acute renal failure]], subcapsular liver hematoma, permanent liver damage, and [[retinal detachment]] occur in about 25% of women.<ref name="ref4"/> Perinatal mortality (stillbirths plus death in infancy) is between 73 and 119 per 1000 babies of woman with HELLP, while up to 40% are [[small for gestational age]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OD3nK6HUIUEC&pg=PA159#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Hypertension in Pregnancy|last=Belfort|first=Michael A.|author2=Steven Thornton|author3=George R. Saade|publisher=CRC Press|year=2002|isbn=9780824708276|location=|pages=159–60|authorlink=|accessdate=2012-04-13}}</ref> In general, however, factors such as gestational age are more important than the severity of HELLP in determining the outcome in the baby.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RuekFAj_tIAC&pg=PA260#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Fetal and Neonatal Brain Injury|last=Stevenson|first=David Kendal|author2=William E. Benītz|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2003|isbn=9780521806916|location=|page=260|authorlink=|accessdate=2012-04-13}}</ref> ==Epidemiology== HELLP syndrome affects 10-20% of pre-eclampsia patients and is a complication in 0.5-0.9% of all pregnancies.<ref name="ref5">{{cite journal | vauthors=Sibai BM, Taslimi MM, el-Nazer A, Amon E, Mabie BC, Ryan GM | title=Maternal-perinatal outcome associated with the syndrome of hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets in severe preeclampsia-eclampsia | journal=J Perinat Med | volume =155 | issue = 3 | pages = 501–9 | date = September 1986 | pmid=3529964 }}</ref><ref name="ref4">{{cite journal | vauthors=Sibai BM, Ramadan MK, Usta I, Salama M, Mercer BM, Friedman SA| title=Maternal morbidity and mortality in 442 pregnancies with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets (HELLP syndrome) | journal=Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume =169 | issue = 4 | pages = 1000–6 | date = October 1993 | pmid=8238109}}</ref><ref name="ref6">{{cite journal | vauthors=Santema JG, Koppelaar I, Wallenburg HC| title=Hypertensive disorders in twin pregnancy | journal=Eur J Obstet Gynecol Reprod Biol | volume =58| issue = 1 | pages = 13–9 | date = January 1995 | pmid=7758654}}</ref> Caucasian women over 25 years of age comprise most of the diagnosed HELLP syndrome cases.<ref name="ref7">{{cite journal | vauthors=Padden MO| title=HELLP syndrome: recognition and perinatal management | journal=Am Fam Physician | volume =60 | issue = 3 | pages = 829–36, 839 | date = September 1999 | pmid=10498110 | doi=10.1515/JPM.2002.076}}</ref> In 70% of cases before childbirth, the condition manifests in the third trimester, but 10% and 20% of the cases exhibit symptoms before and after the third trimester, respectively. Postpartum occurrences are also observed in 30% of all HELLP syndrome cases.<ref name=ref4 /><ref name="ref8">{{cite journal | vauthors=Barton JR, Sibai BM| title=Diagnosis and management of hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets syndrome | journal=Clin Perinatol | volume =31 | issue = 4 | pages = 807–33 | date = December 2004 | pmid=15519429 | doi=10.1016/j.clp.2004.06.008}}</ref>
==History== HELLP syndrome was identified as a distinct clinical entity (as opposed to severe pre-eclampsia) by Dr. Louis Weinstein in 1982.<ref name="ref1"/> In a 2005 article, Weinstein wrote that the unexplained postpartum death of a woman who had haemolysis, abnormal liver function, thrombocytopenia, and hypoglycemia motivated him to review the medical literature and to compile information on similar women.<ref name="ref28"/> He noted that cases with features of HELLP had been reported as early as 1954.<ref name="ref28"/><ref name="Pritchard-1954">{{Cite journal|date=Jan 1954|title=Intravascular hemolysis, thrombocytopenia and other hematologic abnormalities associated with severe toxemia of pregnancy|journal=N Engl J Med|volume=250|issue=3|pages=89–98|doi=10.1056/NEJM195401212500301|vauthors=Pritchard JA, ((Weisman R Jr)), Ratnoff OD, Vosburgh GJ|pmid=13119851}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Acute fatty liver of pregnancy]] *[[Hypertrophic decidual vasculopathy]]
